message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Political Polarization on Twitter
Paper Abstract: In this study we investigate how social media shape the networked public sphere and facilitate communication between communities with different political orientations. We examine two networks of political communication on Twitter, comprised of more than 250,000 tweets from the six weeks leading up to the 2010 U.S. congressional midterm elections. Using a combination of network clustering algorithms and manually-annotated data we demonstrate that the network of political retweets exhibits a highly segregated partisan structure, with extremely limited connectivity between left- and right-leaning users. Surprisingly this is not the case for the user-to-user mention network, which is dominated by a single politically heterogeneous cluster of users in which ideologically-opposed individuals interact at a much higher rate compared to the network of retweets. To explain the distinct topologies of the retweet and mention networks we conjecture that politically motivated individuals provoke interaction by injecting partisan content into information streams whose primary audience consists of ideologically-opposed users. We conclude with statistical evidence in support of this hypothesis.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about Twitter:

## Overview

Twitter, Inc. was an American social media company based in San Francisco, California, which operated and was named for its flagship social media network prior to its rebrand as X.(no content)It is one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.

## Core Features

Users can share short text messages, images, and videos in short posts (commonly and unofficially known as "tweets") and like other users' content.(no content)Users could share concise text messages, images, and videos through "tweets" and engage with other users' content via likes or "retweets".

## Recent Developments

Twitter was an American social networking service that was rebranded as X in 2023.(no content)Twitter, Inc. was merged with X Corp. in April 2023. X Corp. itself was merged with Musk's startup xAI in March 2025, nearly 2 years later.

## User Base

By the start of 2019, Twitter had more than 330 million monthly active users. The platform became known for its active role in political discourse and real-time news sharing.

The platform now operates under the name X following its rebranding and continued evolution under new ownership.

Web search results for query: "political polarization"

Links: [{"title":"Political polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization"},{"title":"Political polarization in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"File:The IRA, Social Media and Political Polarization in the United States, 2012-2018.pdf - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_IRA,_Social_Media_and_Political_Polarization_in_the_United_States,_2012-2018.pdf"},{"title":"Political polarization in Turkey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_Turkey"},{"title":"Negative partisanship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_partisanship"},{"title":"Partisan sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_sorting"},{"title":"August 2023 Ohio Issue 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_2023_Ohio_Issue_1"},{"title":"2025 North Macedonian local elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_North_Macedonian_local_elections"},{"title":"Ground News - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ground_News"},{"title":"Millennial politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millennial_politics"}]

I've performed a web search on political polarization. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Characteristics

Political polarization is the divergence of political attitudes away from the center, towards ideological extremes.(no content)Scholars distinguish between ideological polarization (differences between the policy positions) and affective polarization (an emotional dislike and distrust of political out-groups).

## Types of Polarization

Political scientists identify two main levels:

- "Elite polarization" focuses on the polarization of the political elites, like party organizers and elected officials.
- "Mass polarization" (or popular polarization) focuses on the polarization of the masses, most often the electorate or general public.

## Polarization in the United States

In the late 20th and early 21st century, the U.S. has experienced a greater surge in ideological polarization and affective polarization than comparable democracies.(no content)Polarization has increased since the 1970s, with rapid increases in polarization during the 2000s onwards.(no content)According to the Pew Research Center, members of both parties who have unfavorable opinions of the opposing party have doubled since 1994, while those who have very unfavorable opinions of the opposing party are at record highs as of 2022.

## Related Phenomena

Negative partisanship is the tendency of some voters to form their political opinions primarily in opposition to political parties they dislike.(no content)Partisan sorting is an effect in politics in which voters sort themselves into parties that match their ideology, and is distinct from political polarization, which is where partisans subscribe to increasingly extreme positions.

Web search results for query: "network analysis social networks"

Links: [{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Social network analysis software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis_software"},{"title":"Social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network"},{"title":"Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science"},{"title":"Network theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_theory"},{"title":"Category:Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Dynamic network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_network_analysis"},{"title":"EgoNet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EgoNet"},{"title":"Category:Network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Network_analysis"},{"title":"International Network for Social Network Analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Network_for_Social_Network_Analysis"}]

I've completed the web search for "network analysis social networks". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory.(no content)It characterizes networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

## Applications

Examples of social structures commonly visualized through social network analysis include social media networks, meme proliferation, information circulation, friendship and acquaintance networks, business networks, knowledge networks, difficult working relationships, collaboration graphs, kinship, disease transmission, and sexual relationships.

## Historical Development

Social network analysis has its theoretical roots in the work of early sociologists such as Georg Simmel and Émile Durkheim, who wrote about the importance of studying patterns of relationships that connect social actors. Social scientists have used the concept of "social networks" since early in the 20th century to connote complex sets of relationships between members of social systems at all scales, from interpersonal to international.

## Visualization and Metrics

These networks are often visualized through sociograms in which nodes are represented as points and ties are represented as lines.(no content)Metrics encountered in social network analysis include those measuring the size, the nature of connections between members being analyzed, distribution, and segmentation - including subsets such as multiplexity, propinquity, density, centrality, and cohesion.

## Contemporary Applications

Social network analysis has found applications in various academic disciplines as well as practical contexts such as countering money laundering and terrorism.

Links: [{"title":"2010 United States elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_elections"},{"title":"2010 United States House of Representatives elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections"},{"title":"2010 United States Senate elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_elections"},{"title":"2010 United States state legislative elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_state_legislative_elections"},{"title":"United States midterm election - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_midterm_election"},{"title":"2010s in United States history - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010s_in_United_States_political_history"},{"title":"2010 United States gubernatorial elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_gubernatorial_elections"},{"title":"Midterm election - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-term_elections"},{"title":"2010 United States Senate election in Pennsylvania - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_United_States_Senate_election_in_Pennsylvania"},{"title":"2012 United States House of Representatives elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of the 2010 United States midterm elections:

## Overview

Elections were held in the United States on November 2, 2010, in the middle of Democratic President Barack Obama's first term.(no content)The election was widely characterized as a "Republican wave" election, and President Obama called it "a shellacking."

## Results

Republicans ended unified Democratic control of Congress and the presidency by winning a majority in the House of Representatives and gained seats in the Senate despite Democrats holding Senate control. 

**House of Representatives:** Republicans won the nationwide popular vote for the House of Representatives by a margin of 6.8 points and picked up 63 seats, taking control of the chamber for the first time since the 2006 elections. This represented the largest single-election shift in House seats since the 1948 elections and the largest midterm election shift since the 1938 elections.

**Senate:** Republicans gained seven seats in the Senate (including a special election held in January 2010) but failed to gain a majority in the chamber.

**State Elections:** In state elections, Republicans won a net gain of six gubernatorial seats and flipped control of twenty state legislative chambers, giving them a substantial advantage in the redistricting that occurred following the 2010 United States census.

## Voter Participation

Approximately 82.5 million people voted.

## Key Issues

Voters were motivated for and against the sweeping reforms of the health care system enacted by Democrats in 2010, as well as concerns over tax rates and record deficits. At the time of the election, unemployment was over 9%, and had not declined significantly since Barack Obama had become president.

Elections were held in the United States on November 2, 2010, in the middle of Democratic President Barack Obama's first term.(no content)The election was widely characterized as a "Republican wave" election, and President Obama called it "a shellacking."

## Results

Republicans ended unified Democratic control of Congress and the presidency by winning a majority in the House of Representatives and gained seats in the Senate despite Democrats holding Senate control. 

**House of Representatives:** Republicans won the nationwide popular vote for the House of Representatives by a margin of 6.8 points and picked up 63 seats, taking control of the chamber for the first time since the 2006 elections. This represented the largest single-election shift in House seats since the 1948 elections and the largest midterm election shift since the 1938 elections.

**Senate:** Republicans gained seven seats in the Senate (including a special election held in January 2010) but failed to gain a majority in the chamber.

**State Elections:** In state elections, Republicans won a net gain of six gubernatorial seats and flipped control of twenty state legislative chambers, giving them a substantial advantage in the redistricting that occurred following the 2010 United States census.

## Voter Participation

Approximately 82.5 million people voted.

## Key Issues

Voters were motivated for and against the sweeping reforms of the health care system enacted by Democrats in 2010, as well as concerns over tax rates and record deficits. At the time of the election, unemployment was over 9%, and had not declined significantly since Barack Obama had become president.

Links: [{"title":"Cluster analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster_analysis"},{"title":"Clustering coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clustering_coefficient"},{"title":"Hierarchical clustering of networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_clustering_of_networks"},{"title":"HCS clustering algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HCS_clustering_algorithm"},{"title":"Community structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_structure"},{"title":"KHOPCA clustering algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KHOPCA_clustering_algorithm"},{"title":"Spectral clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_clustering"},{"title":"Automatic clustering algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_clustering_algorithms"},{"title":"Model-based clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-based_clustering"},{"title":"Correlation clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlation_clustering"}]

I've completed a web search for "cluster analysis network algorithm." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Cluster analysis refers to a family of algorithms and tasks rather than one specific algorithm, with various algorithms differing significantly in their understanding of what constitutes a cluster and how to efficiently find them.

## Key Network-Based Clustering Approaches

**Graph-Based Models:**
A clique—a subset of nodes in a graph such that every two nodes are connected by an edge—can be considered a prototypical form of cluster.(no content)Relaxations of the complete connectivity requirement are known as quasi-cliques, as in the HCS clustering algorithm.

**Specific Algorithms:**

- **HCS Algorithm**: The Highly Connected Subgraphs (HCS) clustering algorithm is an algorithm based on graph connectivity for cluster analysis that works by representing similarity data in a similarity graph and finding all highly connected subgraphs.

- **Hierarchical Clustering**: As links are added, connected subsets begin to form, representing the network's community structures.

- **Spectral Clustering**: Spectral clustering techniques use the spectrum (eigenvalues) of the similarity matrix of the data to perform dimensionality reduction before clustering, with the similarity matrix consisting of quantitative assessments of relative similarity between pairs of points.

- **KHOPCA Algorithm**: KHOPCA provides a fully distributed and localized approach to group elements such as nodes in a network according to their distance from each other.

These algorithms serve various applications including social network analysis, community detection, and biological network analysis.

Links: [{"title":"Public sphere - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_sphere"},{"title":"European public sphere - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_public_sphere"},{"title":"Public sphere pedagogy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_sphere_pedagogy"},{"title":"New media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_media"},{"title":"Media (communication) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medium_(communication)"},{"title":"The Structural Transformation of the Public Sphere - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Structural_Transformation_of_the_Public_Sphere"},{"title":"The Public Sphere: An Encyclopedia Article (1964) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Public_Sphere:_An_Encyclopedia_Article_(1964)"},{"title":"Study of global communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Study_of_Global_Communication"},{"title":"Politics and technology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics_and_technology"},{"title":"Public - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public"}]

I've found comprehensive information about public sphere media communication. Here are the key findings:

## Definition of Public Sphere

The public sphere is an area in social life where individuals can come together to freely discuss and identify societal problems, and through that discussion, influence political action.(no content)The term was originally coined by German philosopher Jürgen Habermas who defined the public sphere as "made up of private people gathered together as a public and articulating the needs of society with the state".

## Role of Media in the Public Sphere

Public debate takes place mostly through the mass media, but also at meetings or through social media, academic publications, and government policy documents.(no content)In his theory, Jürgen Habermas argues that the public sphere requires "specific means for transmitting information and influencing those who receive it" In other words, media are essential to constitute and maintain a public sphere.

## Evolution to Digital Spaces

The public sphere no longer requires a physical setting, but can manifest in cyberspace. The coffee house discussions idealized by Habermas have expanded to blogs, discussion forums, and online videos.(no content)The digital public sphere comprises all forms of new media—such as chat rooms, website comment sections, and social media—in which private citizens engage in discourse as a public.

## Challenges and Criticisms

The public sphere, simultaneously restructured and dominated by the mass media, developed into an arena infiltrated by power in which, by means of topic selection and topical contributions, a battle is fought not only over influence but over the control of communication flows. Additionally, individual preferences reveal an unequal spread of social ties with a few giant nodes such as Google, Yahoo, Facebook and YouTube attracting the majority of users.

The public sphere, simultaneously restructured and dominated by the mass media, developed into an arena infiltrated by power in which, by means of topic selection and topical contributions, a battle is fought not only over influence but over the control of communication flows. I've found comprehensive information about public sphere media communication. Here are the key findings:

## Definition of Public Sphere

The public sphere is an area in social life where individuals can come together to freely discuss and identify societal problems, and through that discussion, influence political action.(no content)The term was originally coined by German philosopher Jürgen Habermas who defined the public sphere as "made up of private people gathered together as a public and articulating the needs of society with the state".

## Role of Media in the Public Sphere

Public debate takes place mostly through the mass media, but also at meetings or through social media, academic publications, and government policy documents.(no content)In his theory, Jürgen Habermas argues that the public sphere requires "specific means for transmitting information and influencing those who receive it" In other words, media are essential to constitute and maintain a public sphere.

## Evolution to Digital Spaces

The public sphere no longer requires a physical setting, but can manifest in cyberspace. The coffee house discussions idealized by Habermas have expanded to blogs, discussion forums, and online videos.(no content)The digital public sphere comprises all forms of new media—such as chat rooms, website comment sections, and social media—in which private citizens engage in discourse as a public.

## Challenges and Criticisms

The public sphere, simultaneously restructured and dominated by the mass media, developed into an arena infiltrated by power in which, by means of topic selection and topical contributions, a battle is fought not only over influence but over the control of communication flows. Additionally, individual preferences reveal an unequal spread of social ties with a few giant nodes such as Google, Yahoo, Facebook and YouTube attracting the majority of users.

I've completed a web search for "retweet social media." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Functionality

Retweeting (officially reposting since July 2023) is the mechanism in social media which allows users to repost the content of another user's post with an indication that the source of the post is another user. On Twitter/X specifically, users can interact with tweets by 'retweeting' (reblogging), liking, quoting the tweet, or replying to it.

## History

In November 2009, Twitter began rolling out the ability to 'retweet' a tweet. Prior to this, people would write "RT @username" before quoting the original tweet.(no content)The "retweet" phenomenon began in March 2007, and a month later the term "retweet" was first referenced, with a protocol developing where a post by User A which was considered notable by another Twitter user, User B, was copied by User B and reposted under User B's account and prefixed with "RT @username", with "RT" meaning "retweet".

## Recent Changes

Following the acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk in October 2022, and rebranding of the site as "X" in July 2023, all references to the word "tweet" were removed from the service, changed to "post", and "retweet" changed to "repost". However, the terms "tweet" and "retweet" are still more popular when referring to posts on X.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.
